Issues.Title: fix(bazel): only providing stamping information if the --stamp flag is used
Issues.Body:
Previously the volatile status file was always provided to the ng_rollup
action which prevented it from being cacheable remotely.  This change to
only provide this file as an input when the --stamp flag is used will allow
for the action to be remotely cached and prevent needing to run the action
on every CI run.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(bazel): only providing stamping information if the --stamp flag is used" (#39392)

Issues.Title: feat(core): schematic to migrate invalid interpolation-like markup
Issues.Body:
This commit introduces a schematic that fixes interpolation-like markup
no longer accepted by the Anuglar compiler since invalidated by #39107.

Previously, the angular parser would not match markup like
`{{ 1 + 2 }` or `{{ 1 + 2 }<!-- -->}` to be partial (but malformed)
interpolations, an implementation detail that some developers may have
relied on to treat interpolation-like markup as text.

However, this kind of markup may be ambiguous, and since #39107, is not
well-formed. In such cases it is preferred to use an interpolation
directly or escape interpolation delimiters (e.g. `{{ '{{' }} 1 + 2
{{ '}}' }}`). This commit provides fixes for malformed cases so as to
ease migration for applications relying on the previous implementation.

Part of #38596

Issues.Title: Methods on FormControl to allow de-registration of change and disabled handlers
Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

Oh hi there! 😄 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅-->


# 🚀 feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: --> This feature request is for @angular/forms


### Description
<!-- ✍️--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
Current implementation of FormControl does not allow de-registration change and disabled handlers (ones registered by `registerOnChange` and `registerOnDsiabledChange`). I have a use case where we're being provided a externally build `FormControl`, which we'd like to treat as readonly effectively and would like to register for disabled handling but we'd want to clean it up once our own code goes out of scope (by which I mean someone externally calls `destroy` on our object).


### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ✍️--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
Looking at current implementation of FormControl, we'd just need to add `deregisterOnChange` and `deregisterOnDisabledChange` methods to the public API which allows the programmer to pass in the same function ref as one passed in during registration and internally the FormControl would do something like a `this._onChange = this._onChange.filter(fn => fn !== handler)` (where `handler` is an argument to the method). Same idea as `addEventListener` and `removeEventListener`.

If this solution is viable, I can try to get it working and submit a PR.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ✍️--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
1. Current work around we've got involves casting to `any` and performing this removal ourselves.
2. We could listen to `formControl.statusChanges` but I don't believe there is a `ENABLED` event but there is a `DISABLED` event? And I don't know what 'VALID' mean in this context? If there is a validation error but we do `enable()` what emits? `VALID`? `INVALID`? In my opinion this is confusing and hence in the application code I've decided to use `registerOnDiabledChange` instead of relying on `statusChanges` for keeping track of disabled changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Methods on FormControl to allow de-registration of change and disabled handlers" (#39390)

Issues.Title: ng xi18n --ivy doesn't extract strings from 3rd party libraries
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package `@angular/localize` ### Is this a regression? Yes, it works without `--ivy` option ### Description I'm using `ng-bootstrap`. When I run `ng xi18n` without `--ivy`, the tool does extract strings from my app and the library (ng-bootstrap). As a result, `messages.xlf` contains entries like: ``` ... node_modules/@ng-bootstrap/ng-bootstrap/timepicker/timepicker.d.ts 76 ... ``` When I run `ng xi18n --ivy`, these trans-units are missing. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/kamilchlebek/i18n-ivy-es5/tree/ng-bootstrap ## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:**

Issues.Title: ngOnInit does not fire when going back/forward to/from an external domain in Safari 14.0 and iOS browsers.
Issues.Body:
This seems as though it may be a duplicate of #26829 but I have a repro here. The workarounds provided in that issue thread do not seem to work. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction & Description I created a brand new repo here: https://github.com/jdpearce/jhp-safari-back This is deployed in two places: http://jhp-safari-back.herokuapp.com/ http://jhp-safari-back2.herokuapp.com/ If you open up the first instance in Safari 14.0 and then click "external" it will navigate to the second instance. Click "back" and you can see that the text in the template has _not_ been updated (the time remains the same as when the page was first visited) - i.e. `ngOnInit` has not fired. If you click between "one" and "two" on the same domain that text is updated on each visit. e.g. ![angular_safari_back_bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/439121/96857567-0693ec80-1457-11eb-85d6-eff9131389eb.gif) ## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 10.1.7
Node: 12.16.3
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 10.2.0
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1001.7
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1001.7
@angular-devkit/core            10.1.7
@angular-devkit/schematics      10.1.7
@angular/cli                    10.1.7
@schematics/angular             10.1.7
@schematics/update              0.1001.7
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      3.9.7
**Anything else relevant?** This is specific to Safari 14.0 and ALL browsers on iOS I understand this may be a problem with Safari/WebKit itself, but even if it's not a bug in Angular per se, advice on how best to overcome this would be enormously welcome. Thanks!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ngOnInit does not fire when going back/forward to/from an external domain in Safari 14.0 and iOS browsers." (#39382)

Issues.Title: service worker won't register after .unregister()
Issues.Body:
<!--
IF YOU DON'T FILL OUT THE FOLLOWING INFORMATION YOUR ISSUE MIGHT BE CLOSED WITHOUT INVESTIGATING
-->
### Bug Report or Feature Request (mark with an `x`)
```
- [ x ] bug report -> please search issues before submitting
- [ ] feature request
```

### Area
```
- [ x? ] devkit
- [ ] schematics
```

### Versions
<!--
Output from: `node --version` and `npm --version`.
  Windows (7/8/10). Linux (incl. distribution). macOS (El Capitan? Sierra? High Sierra?)
-->
node --version v8.11.2
npm -v 6.1.0

### Repro steps
<!--
Simple steps to reproduce this bug.
Please include: commands run, packages added, related code changes.
A link to a sample repo would help too.
-->

on logout we do:
````
          // unregister service worker
          navigator.serviceWorker.getRegistrations().then(function (registrations) {
            for (const registration of registrations) {
              registration.unregister();
            }
          });
````
Then we reload the site.. when user loggs back in there is no service worker registered

### The log given by the failure
<!-- Normally this include a stack trace and some more information. -->


### Desired functionality
<!--
What would like to see implemented?
What is the usecase?
-->
Service worker should register

### Mention any other details that might be useful
<!-- Please include a link to the repo if this is related to an OSS project. -->

If we manually do this in the console:

````
navigator.serviceWorker.register('/ngsw-worker.js')
````
then things start working again
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "service worker won't register after .unregister()" (#39377)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler): parse bindings "by hand" rather than via regex
Issues.Body:
To support recovery of malformed binding property names like `([a)`,
`[a`, or `()`, the binding parser needs to be more permissive w.r.t. the
kinds of bindings it can detect. This is difficult to do maintainably
with a regex, but is trivial with a "hand-rolled" string parser. This
commit refactors render3's binding attribute parsing to use this method
for multi-delimited bindings (namely via the `()`, `[]`, and `[()]`)
syntax, making the way recovery of malformed bindings in a future patch.

Note that we can keep using a regex for prefix-only binding syntax
(e.g. `bind-`, `ref-`) because validation of the binding is complete
once we have matched the prefix, and the only thing left to do is check
that the binding identifier is non-empty, which is trivial.

Part of #38596

Issues.Title: ci(angular/dev-infra): add CI checks to ensure `lock-closed` action is built correctly
Issues.Body:
**The problem**

Currently, the [angular/dev-infra](https://github.com/angular/dev-infra) repository relies on a [pre-commit git hook][1] for building the `lock-closed` action, in order to ensure that the changes made in the source code (e.g. [src/main.ts][2]) will also be included in the built script that is actually used when running the action (i.e. [lib/bundle.js][3]).

However, it is easy to miss this step (for example if someone submit a PR via the GitHub UI or commits review suggestions via the GitHub UI or has git hooks disabled, etc.).

This can result in issues such as #39358, where the fix is in the source code but not in the built script (that is actually used).

##
**The solution**

Introduce CI checks to `angular/dev-infra` that would ensure that the built script (`lib/bundle.js`) is indeed up-to-date with the source code (`src/main.ts`).

[1]: https://github.com/angular/dev-infra/blob/414834b2b24dd2df37c6ed00808387ee6fd91b66/scripts/pre-commit.sh#L5
[2]: https://github.com/angular/dev-infra/blob/414834b2b24dd2df37c6ed00808387ee6fd91b66/github-actions/lock-closed/src/main.ts#L35
[3]: https://github.com/angular/dev-infra/blob/414834b2b24dd2df37c6ed00808387ee6fd91b66/github-actions/lock-closed/lib/bundle.js#L26099
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ci(angular/dev-infra): add CI checks to ensure `lock-closed` action is built correctly" (#39372)

Issues.Title: [docs-infra] Update angular.io deployments to match new versioning/branching process
Issues.Body:
This issue is for tracking progress on updating angular.io deployments to match our [new versioning/branching process](https://docs.google.com/document/d/197kVillDwx-RZtSVOBtPb4BBIAw0E9RT3q3v6DZkykU). ## Planning 1. **What Firebase projects/sites need to be created?** - [x] `angular-io > v2-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v4-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v5-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v6-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v7-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v8-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v9-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v10-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > v11-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > rc-angular-io-site` - [x] `angular-io > next-angular-io-site`
> **Note 1:** The [`angular-io` Firebase project](https://console.firebase.google.com/u/0/project/angular-io/hosting) will be the canonical one, so all sites should be created there. > **Note 2:** There is Firebase project named `v10-angular-io` and therefore we are not allowed to have `v10-angular-io` site. For consistency, all site names should have a `-site` suffix (i.e. `-angular-io-site`).
2. **What Firebase projects/sites will be obsolete (and can be deleted **at the very end**)?** - [ ] `v2-angular-io` - [ ] `v4-angular-io` - [ ] `v5-angular-io` - [ ] `v6-angular-io` - [ ] `v7-angular-io` - [ ] `v8-angular-io` - [ ] `aio-staging` (including `aio-staging > v9-angular-io`)
3. **What DNS/Firebase redirects do we need?** - [ ] `v2.angular.io` --> `angular-io > v2-angular-io-site` (previously `v2-angular-io`) - [ ] `v4.angular.io` --> `angular-io > v4-angular-io-site` (previously `v4-angular-io`) - [ ] `v5.angular.io` --> `angular-io > v5-angular-io-site` (previously `v5-angular-io`) - [ ] `v6.angular.io` --> `angular-io > v6-angular-io-site` (previously `v6-angular-io`) - [ ] `v7.angular.io` --> `angular-io > v7-angular-io-site` (previously `v7-angular-io`) - [ ] `v8.angular.io` --> `angular-io > v8-angular-io-site` (previously `v8-angular-io`) - [ ] `v9.angular.io` --> `angular-io > v9-angular-io-site` (previously `aio-staging > v9-angular-io`) - [ ] `www.angular.io` --> `angular.io` --> `angular-io > v10-angular-io-site` (previously `angular-io`) - [ ] `rc.angular.io` --> `angular-io > rc-angular-io-site` (previously `-`) - [ ] `next.angular.io` --> `angular-io > next-angular-io-site` (previously `aio-staging`)
4. **What existing projects/sites need to be cloned (and where to)?** - [x] `v2-angular-io` --> `angular-io > v2-angular-io-site` - [x] `v4-angular-io` --> `angular-io > v4-angular-io-site` - [x] `v5-angular-io` --> `angular-io > v5-angular-io-site` - [x] `v6-angular-io` --> `angular-io > v6-angular-io-site` - [x] `v7-angular-io` --> `angular-io > v7-angular-io-site` - [ ] (`v8-angular-io` --> `angular-io > v8-angular-io-site` - will be deployed when we update the merge scripts) - [ ] (`aio-staging > v9-angular-io` --> `angular-io > v9-angular-io-site` - will be deployed when we update the merge scripts) - [ ] (`angular-io` --> `angular-io > v10-angular-io-site` - will be deployed when we update the merge scripts) - [ ] (`aio-staging` --> `angular-io > rc-angular-io-site` - will be deployed when we update the merge scripts) - [ ] (`aio-staging` --> `angular-io > next-angular-io-site` - will be deployed when we update the merge scripts)
5. **What branches need to be updated for future deployements (all active LTS and releasable branches)?** - [ ] `8.2.x` (for https://v8.angular.io/) - [ ] `9.1.x` (for https://v9.angular.io/) - [ ] `10.1.x` (for https://angular.io/) - [ ] `11.0.x` (for https://rc.angular.io/) - [ ] `master` (for https://next.angular.io/) --- ## Execution - [x] **1.** Create the necessary projects/sites. - [ ] **2.** Manually re-upload latest minor versions of all (non-releasable) majors to sites. ([Version cloning](https://firebase.googleblog.com/2020/10/preview-channels-firebase-hosting.html)) _I cloned the version (using `firebase hosting:clone`), but it seems to only clone the content and not the hosting config. Looking for another way to address that (hopefully without having to build each version from the sources 😱)._ - [ ] **3.** Create PRs for all necessary branches to deploy to both locations (old project + new site). - [ ] **4.** Create follow-up PRs to deploy only to sites. - [ ] **5.** Merge PRs from step (3). - [ ] **6.** Verify sites work (for merged PRs and manually cloned versions). - [ ] **7.** Update DNS/Firebase redirects. - [ ] **8.** Merge PRs from step (4). - [ ] **9.** Verify all versions have been successfully deployed to sites (by looking at the deployed SHA in the footer). - [ ] **10.** Verify sub-domains work and point to sites (by looking at the deployed SHA in the footer). - [ ] **11.** Delete unnecessary projects/sites.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[docs-infra] Update angular.io deployments to match new versioning/branching process" (#39366)

Issues.Title: ComponentRef<T> onDestroyed() callback does not get called
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: Pre-Ivy or if you disable Ivy ### Description **Problem: ComponentRef.onDestroyed callback does not get called** A component gets dynamically created via `ComponentFactoryResolver`. It is then inserted into the view. ```typescript @ViewChild("anchor", { read: ViewContainerRef }) anchor: ViewContainerRef; ``` ```typescript this.compRef = this.cfr .resolveComponentFactory(DynamicComponent) .create(this.injector); this.compRef.onDestroy(() => console.log("DynamicComponent onDestroyed callback") ); this.anchor.insert(this.compRef.hostView); ``` As you can see, the `onDestroyed` callback is attached. If the component gets destroyed by its ComponentRef, the callback **gets called correctly** like so: ```typescript this.compRef.destroy(); ``` if the component gets destroyed by clearing the `anchor`, the callback **does not get called**: ```typescript this.anchor.clear(); ``` As far as I can tell, the `onDestroyed` callback **ONLY** gets called when the component gets destroyed by its `ComponentRef`. Whenever the component gets destroyed by clearing parent views or navigating away or data binding, the callback does not get called. It works in NG 8.2.14 and it works if you set `enableIvy: false` in tsconfig.json. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction [https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-ev4v2y](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-ev4v2y) ## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 10.1.6
Node: 12.18.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 10.1.5
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... platform-webworker, router
Ivy Workspace: No

Issues.Title: Add CSS webpack-dev-server HMR when using component styles
Issues.Body:
**I'm submitting a ...**  (check one with "x")

```
[ ] bug report => search github for a similar issue or PR before submitting
[X] feature request
[ ] support request => Please do not submit support request here, instead see https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#question
```

**Current behavior** 

<!-- Describe how the bug manifests. -->

Although the Angular+Webpack docs present the combo as "an excellent alternative to the SystemJS approach", loading component styles via `styles` or `styleUrls` results in a full page refresh, instead of style injection, which occurs when using SystemJS+lite-server.

**Expected behavior**

<!-- Describe what the behavior would be without the bug. -->

A core feature of using Webpack+Webpack-dev-server in development is the availability of Hot Module Replacement. It is expected that HMR would work for css injection regardless of the style loading strategy used. Instead, currently changes to css or scss files which are included in a component's styles result in a full page reload.

**Reproduction of the problem**

<!-- If the current behavior is a bug or you can illustrate your feature request better with an example, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem via https://plnkr.co or similar (you can use this template as a starting point: http://plnkr.co/edit/tpl:AvJOMERrnz94ekVua0u5). -->

**What is the motivation / use case for changing the behavior?**

<!-- Describe the motivation or the concrete use case -->

Speed up the Angular 2 development process for CSS developers

**Please tell us about your environment:**

<!-- Operating system, IDE, package manager, HTTP server, ... -->
- **Angular version:** 2.0.0
  
  <!-- Check whether this is still an issue in the most recent Angular version -->
- **Browser:** [**_all_** | Chrome XX | Firefox XX | IE XX | Safari XX | Mobile Chrome XX | Android X.X Web Browser | iOS XX Safari | iOS XX UIWebView | iOS XX WKWebView ] 
  
  <!-- All browsers where this could be reproduced -->

- **Webpack-dev-server version:** 1.14.1

Issues.Title: More accurate progress reporting in `ng build`
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request
When running `ng build`, the progress percentage is limited to Webpack execution which is only one component of the build. This means the reported progress is not very helpful or useful. Ideally, this should reflect the entirety of the `ng build` process to give more accurate measurement.

Users tend to think of percentage progress as representing time the process with take. Since it is very hard to know how long a given build step will take (for example, `tsc` and Terser tend to take the longest, while index file generation is pretty quick), it may make more sense to report steps rather than percentage. The CLI could print "Executing step 4/9 - Compiling TypeScript" to be more clear that 44% of build time has not passed, but rather we're running the 4th of 9 build steps, each of which could take an unspecified and non-equivalent length of time. We should also include a spinner just to show that work is being done, since individual build steps may take a long time and we don't want the user to think the CLI is frozen when it is not.

Ideally, we would have such progress reporting in all non-trivial CLI commands, but for now, we'll limit this issue to just `ng build` and `ng serve`, which is where users will be spending 99% of their time anyways.

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [X] build
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "More accurate progress reporting in `ng build`" (#19181)

Issues.Title: docs: add `rm -rf node_modules/` to release docs
Issues.Body:
In the latest release, I was not able to build even after running `yarn` to refresh dependencies. Eventually, we tracked
the issue down to `rm -rf node_modules/`. There may be some instances where this can be necessary to ensure clean
builds.

I opted to just include this change directly in the commands to be more clear that people saw it. If devs want to be lazy they can always skip that step, but they will hopefully at least see it and be reminded that if something doesn't work, they should at least try `rm -rf node_modules/`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs: add `rm -rf node_modules/` to release docs" (#19180)

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): Schematic to migrate invalid interpolations
Issues.Body:
This commit adds a migration schematic to fix interpolation-like markup
now invalidated by #39107. Previously, the angular parser would not
match markup like `{{ 1 + 2 }` or `{{ 1 + 2 }<!-- -->}` to be partial
(but malformed) interpolations, an implementation detail that some
developers may have relied on to treat interpolation-like markup as
text. #39107 changes the parser implementation to know emit errors in
such cases, because the markup looks like an interpolation but is not
well-formed. In such cases it is preferred to use an interpolation
directly or escape interpolation delimiters (e.g. `{{ '{{' }} 1 + 2
{{ '}}' }}`). This commit provides fixes for malformed cases so as to
ease migration for applications relying on the previous implementation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@schematics/angular): Schematic to migrate invalid interpolations" (#19177)

Issues.Title: can't use `ng new` to create a different project
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] new ### Description It's impossible to create a new project outside the "main project". It's impossible to create a new project inside the "main project". This practically means `ng new` is unusable in its current state. See below. ``` 32ef113d4404:/home/frdev/frontend/xx$ ../node_modules/.bin/ng new shit The new command requires to be run outside of a project, but a project definition was found at "/home/frdev/frontend/angular.json". 32ef113d4404:/home/frdev/frontend/xx$ cd ../../tmp/ 32ef113d4404:/home/frdev/tmp$ ../frontend/node_modules/.bin/ng new blah An invalid configuration file was found ['/home/frdev/frontend/angular.json']. Please delete the file before running the command. ``` It used to work just fine several releases back. Why would it care of angular.json in main project's dir? It's not of its business, it should've just created a new project dir and pulled the deps via `npm`. ## 🌍 Your Environment

Issues.Title: ng serve fails to correctly watch git changes (need to `touch` files to trigger correct builds)
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I think yes, it was working for us I believe in version 7, but a project from scratch shows the error now. ### Description When files are changed by git (for example), the rebuild doesn't happen correctly. There is an error "Module build failed" which seems to come from some virtual file cache that is (I suppose) not correctly invalidated. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction ``` # Create a new Angular Project npm install -g @angular/cli@~10.0.0 # the @~10.0.0 is optional at this moment of course ng new project # I select the following options but I'm not sure it changes anything # ? Would you like to add Angular routing? No # ? Which stylesheet format would you like to use? SCSS [ https://sass-lang.com/documentation/syntax#scss ] cd project # create a new branch git checkout -b rename-component # start the server ng serve --port=4201 # move a component mv src/app/app.component.ts src/app/app2.component.ts # the ng serve commands shows an error, which is expected # open app.module.ts and change the line # import { AppComponent } from './app.component'; # to # import { AppComponent } from './app2.component'; vim app.module.ts # save the file with that change. the app compiles again (expected). # add the changes to the branch git add src # Output is expected : # On branch rename-component # Changes to be committed: # (use "git restore --staged ..." to unstage) # modified: src/app/app.module.ts # renamed: src/app/app.component.ts -> src/app/app2.component.ts # commit git commit -m "rename component" # go back to master, the app rebuilds correctly ` Compiled successfully. ` git checkout master # go back to our branch git checkout rename-component # We have a compilation error !!!! Which is not expected # 4 unchanged chunks # chunk {main} main.js, main.js.map (main) 8.35 kB [initial] [rendered] # Time: 314ms # # ERROR in ./src/app/app2.component.ts # Module build failed (from ./node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/index.js): # Error: /.../project/src/app/app2.component.ts is missing from the TypeScript compilation. Please make sure it is in your tsconfig via the 'files' or 'include' property. # at AngularCompilerPlugin.getCompiledFile (/.../project/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.js:938:23) # at /.../project/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/loader.js:42:31 # at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:97:5) # touch the module file touch src/app/app.module.ts # now it compiles again ! ``` It's not expected to have to save (or touch) module.ts files (or any file, really) when changing from a branch to the other. Files are modified and it should retrigger a compilation, here it seems that the file rename is taken into account but not the module change (because a "touch" on the module makes the compilation work again). This is a minimal reproduction on a very simple app but on a bigger production app where many engineers collaborate, we have to restart ng serve everytime we switch from a branch to another which is a very big pain. ## 🔥 Exception or Error 

ERROR in ./src/app/app2.component.ts
Module build failed (from ./node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/index.js):
Error: /.../project/src/app/app2.component.ts is missing from the TypeScript compilation. Please make sure it is in your tsconfig via the 'files' or 'include' property.
    at AngularCompilerPlugin.getCompiledFile (/.../project/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/angular_compiler_plugin.js:938:23)
    at /.../project/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/loader.js:42:31
    at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:97:5)
## 🌍 Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 10.0.8
Node: 12.19.0
OS: linux x64

Angular: 10.0.14
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): don't add publicHost pathname to sockPath in dev-server

Issues.Body: Closes #16353

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): remove lint fix default value
Issues.Body:
Since will remove lintFix usage warnings when the option is set by a default of another schematic.

Example when executing
```
ng generate module customers --route customers --module app.module
```

The lintFix default of the module schematic will be passed down to the component schematic which would cause a warning to be shown.

Closes #19169
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@schematics/angular): remove lint fix default value" (#19172)

##### Bug Fixes

-   **platform-server:** If you use `useAbsoluteUrl` to setup `platform-server`, you now need to
    also specify `baseUrl`.
    We are intentionally making this a breaking change in a minor release,
    because if `useAbsoluteUrl` is set to `true` then the behavior of the
    application could be unpredictable, resulting in issues that are hard to
    discover but could be affecting production environments.
-   **compiler:** TypeScript 3.9 is no longer supported, please upgrade to TypeScript 4.0.

I managed to update `ng update @angular/cli@7 @angular/core@7` just fine, but next is Material update. I installed all deps manuallly and properly (swimlane charts , etc). Now I'm running material update and it **PULLS** angular **10**. Issues.Title: ng build and serve have different behaviour in overwriting assets when using assets key in angular.json
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? We did not have to use the assets before as on earlier versions this also worked using `fileReplacements`, and that worked correctly in both `ng serve` and `ng build`. This sounds a little like #16670 ### Description When using the `assets` key in the `angular.json` file, and having a rule that overlaps: ``` "assets": [ "src/favicon.ico", "src/assets", { "input": "src/assets-replace", "output": "/assets", "glob": "**/*" } ] ``` The files from `src/assets-replace` will overwite the files in `src/assets` when using `ng build`, but it does not when using `ng serve`. We use this functionality to have different themes of our own app. We use a different configuration for each theme, and have files with the same filename to replace the original logo, like the logo. This not working makes it a little hard to test whether theme changes work correctly. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction - Change `angular.json`, see assets example above. - Add an `image.png` in your assets folder, and display/show it in a component - Add an `assets-replace` folder in your `src` folder and put another `image.png` in it - Execute `ng serve` and see that it will display the image from `src/assets` - Execute `ng build` and see that it will display the image from `src/assets-replace` Example repro repo: https://github.com/jerbob92/angular-cli-assets-overwrite-bug ## 🌍 Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 10.1.7
Node: 12.19.0
OS: linux x64

Angular: 10.1.6
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------

@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1001.7
@angular-devkit/core            10.1.7

Issues.Title: feat(material/datepicker) allow custom pickers with date inputs
Issues.Body:
Refactor material datepicker so apps can bind custom picker components to date inputs.

### API changes
- Renamed the following in `MatDatepickerBase`:
  - `_registerInput()` -> `registerInput()`
  - `_stateChanges` -> `stateChanges`
  - `_datepickerInput` -> `datepickerInput`
- Added `MatDatepickerPanel` interface (recommendations for another name?).
- Refactored `MatDatepickerInput`, `MatDateRangeInput`, and `MatDatepickerToggle` to receive a `MatDatepickerPanel` instead of a specific implementation of `MatDatepickerBase`.

Issues.Title: feat(material): Allow focus origin to be an optional input to focus() methods.
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

WHAT: For Angular Material components that have a focus() method, allow for the origin param to be optional and remove the default origin value.

WHY: For cases where the focus() method is called and the origin is already defined, we don’t want to override the origin using focusVia to always be some default value. In many cases, we want to leave the origin unchanged, but if there are cases that need the origin to be updated, allow for this with an optional origin param.

#### Use Case

If the focus origin value is keyboard, and some interaction happens where we want to set focus to another element somewhere on the page by explicitly calling focus(), then in cases where the focus origin should remain the same, the current implementation causes the origin to change and the interaction to be weird. This is also due to the fact that we use a single, global focus monitor attached to the document body in eventual detection mode. 

Here are the components to update:
-button
-checkbox
-menu item
-menu trigger
-radio
-expansion panel header
-slide toggle
-step header
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(material): Allow focus origin to be an optional input to focus() methods." (#20858)

Issues.Title: bug(Breakpoints): Incorrect upper boundary lead to wrong match result
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://components-issue-r4nh9s.stackblitz.io

Steps to reproduce:
1. change browser size to 960 * 600
2. apply following code
```javascript
this.breakpointObserver.observe(Breakpoints.Handset).subscribe((result) => {
    this.isHandset = result.matches;
});
```
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

matching result should be false

#### Actual Behavior

matching result is true


#### Environment

- Angular: 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10
- CDK/Material: 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10
- Browser(s): Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge
- Operating System: Windows, macOS, Ubuntu

#### How to fix

If we take a look at [Bootstrap](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/v4.4.1/scss/mixins/_breakpoints.scss)'s source code, we can see that, their upper boundary is using numbers like xxx.98, while in [Angular Material](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/10.2.x/src/cdk/layout/breakpoints.ts), the upper boundary is using numbers like xxx.99, and this lead to the bug.
I take size 960*600 as example, in browser, if you match something like
```javascript
'(max-width: 599.99px) and (orientation: portrait), ' +
 '(max-width: 959.99px) and (orientation: landscape)'
```
browser will give you true, only if you match something like
```javascript
'(max-width: 599.98px) and (orientation: portrait), ' +
 '(max-width: 959.98px) and (orientation: landscape)'
```
browser will give you false
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(Breakpoints): Incorrect upper boundary lead to wrong match result" (#20850)

Issues.Title: bug(Dialog Overlay): a11y screen reader issue reading overlay content in dialog
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction
This issue can be reproduced on the dialog example: https://material2-dev.firebaseapp.com/select 

Steps to reproduce:
1. Navigate to Dialog
2. Use the Voice Over (mac screen reader) and open the select drop-down
3. Try to navigate the option with UP/DOWN arrow key. The VO navigation doesn't select the options
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
- Using VO is in safari, DOWN/UP arrow navigation should read/announce the select option.


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
The screen reader does read the selected options in the select component inside the dialog model. 

Relate Issue: https://github.com/angular/components/pull/20695

#### Environment

- Angular: 9+
- CDK/Material: CDK
- Browser(s): Safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS

GIF: http://www.giphy.com/gifs/ZGTv8ZW9I2UtXYOD0x
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(Dialog Overlay): a11y screen reader issue reading overlay content in dialog" (#20840)

Issues.Title: MatTabGroup animation goes the wrong way in RTL
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

StackBlitz to get my issue: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-yxyjcs?file=src/app/example-component.html

Steps to reproduce:
1. move between the tabs by clicking on it, you will find the animation way from left to right not right to left...
2. move between the tabs using the arrows, unacceptable behavior happens... 

#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
The animation should be from right to left when the RTL mode is active.
Pagination Arrow is not working correctly.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
the animation way from left to right in the RTL mode.
unacceptable behavior happens, when using pagination arrow... 

#### Environment

- Angular: **latest**
- CDK/Material: **latest**
- Browser(s): **chrome**
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatTabGroup animation goes the wrong way in RTL" (#20838)
